page.title: 07JOBS IN WOODSPRING VILLAGES
page.content: At one time practically all the working population of villages such as Wick St. Lawrence or Kingston Seymour were employed within the village either on the farms or in businesses connected with agriculture. Since the Second World War farms have become more mechanised and fewer men are needed to work on them. Often only the occupier and family are needed. This means that most people find jobs out- side the villages in every walk of life. The motor car has made this possible. It has also meant that non- villagers have been able to make their homes in the country to everyone's mutual advantage. Moves to bring employment to rural areas are resisted because the building of workshops alters the character of a rural community and puts a strain on roads not designed for heavy traffic.
